section.title: First Conditional
section.sectiontitle: Use the First Conditional to talk about a possible situation in the future.
section.text1a: If you don't eat, you'll be hungry later.
section.text2a: You won't sleep well tonight if you drink all that coffee.
section.sectiontitle2: Make the First Conditional with If + Present Simple + will/won't + verb. If + Present Simple is the 'if clause'. Will/won't + verb is the 'result clause'.
section.text3a: If you eat a lot of junk food, you'll put on weight.
section.text4a: If you don't start training now, you won't be able to run the marathon.

section.title: First Conditional
section.text1a: If we leave at 9.30, we'll be late.
section.text2a: If you don't study, you'll fail your exam.
section.sectiontitle2: The 'if clause' can come first or second.
section.text3a: If you use the cream once a day, you'll have softer skin.
section.text4a: You'll have softer skin if you use the cream once a day.

section.title: First Conditional
section.sectiontitle: When the 'if clause' is first, we need a comma at the end of the clause.
section.text1a: If I don't go to bed now, I'll be tired tomorrow.
section.text2a: I'll be tired tomorrow if I don't go to bed now.
section.sectiontitle2: We can also use other modal verbs in the result clause, e.g. may, might, could.
section.text3a: If I finish this soon, I might go and see Tony.
section.text4a: We could go to the cinema tonight if you want to.
